awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Synthesis, Structural Characterization and Electrochemical Studies of Framework Substituted Germanium and Tin Clathrates
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
The structural integrity of a crystalline material is an important property that can greatly influence its ability to be utilized in practical applications. For electrochemical energy storage devices, daily operation involves the electrochemical insertion and extraction of ions, which is often accompanied by larger structural transformations that may cause the material to collapse. Hence, the search for new electrode materials is necessary in order for future energy storage demands to be realized. Clathrates are a class of materials with cage-like structures that can naturally hold guest ions, a feature that may be exploited in energy storage applications. However, different features in the clathrate bonding arrangement may affect its mechanical integrity. Key objectives of this project are to understand the electrochemical characteristics of these materials, how the structure of the clathrate changes upon electrochemical insertion of guest ions, and the development of new synthetic routes to obtain clathrates. Results from this project enable new knowledge on the intricate relationships among the clathrates' structures and their physical properties, electrochemical characteristics, and structural stability.

Technical Abstract:
The objectives of this project are: (1) to investigate the electrochemical and structural properties of germanium and tin clathrates using first principles calculations and detailed structural characterization to understand the electrochemically obtained structures; and (2) to synthesize new clathrates containing lithium ions from novel precursors. The project uses a concerted approach combining the synthetic, structural and electrochemical characterization, and theoretical expertise of the investigators. The research enables a better understanding of the relationship between the clathrate structure and its physical properties, electrochemical characteristics, and phase stability. These achievements could lead to higher energy density lithium and sodium batteries. The studies also help to build up the predictive power of solid-state chemistry, establishing new ideas of why and how atoms assemble and form new compounds and structures with the desired electrochemical properties. Investigation of these materials involves a collaboration between two universities (Arizona State University and University of Delaware) and three different departments (materials science, chemistry, and physics), which exposes students to multidisciplinary research. Outreach and educational activities engaging students ranging from the middle school to undergraduate levels, with an emphasis on recruiting females into science and engineering and improving student learning and engagement in introductory undergraduate classes.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Materials made from the Tetrel elements (silicon, germanium, tin) have received significant attention as high energy density anodes for Li-ion batteries due to their ability to alloy with large amounts of lithium. This project investigated Tetrel clathrates, materials which have cage-like structures that can accommodate guest atoms such as lithium and sodium. This project aimed to (1) investigate the electrochemical and structural properties of Ge and Sn clathrates upon reaction with lithium through a concerted experimental and theoretical approach, and (2) to develop new synthesis methods and clathrates containing Li from novel precursors.

This multidisciplinary, collaborative project involve PIs with complementary expertise at Arizona State University (Candace K. Chan, materials science and engineering and Xihong Peng, theoretical physics), and the University of Delaware (Svilen Bobev, solid-state chemistry). The research elucidated the relationships between the clathrate structure and their electrochemical properties using experimental and computational methods, including advanced electroanalytical methods, synchrotron characterization, and structural analysis. Comparative studies were performed on silicon, germanium, and tin clathrates and electrodes made from the non-clathrate, elemental counterparts to assess the effect of clathrate structure on electrochemical properties. The project also developed novel synthetic methods for clathrates using solid-state and flux-based electrochemical methods.

The research found that the clathrate composition and structure play an important role in the reaction mechanism of electrochemical ion insertion. Tuning of the guest atom and framework composition can cause the reaction to favor amorphization or reversible insertion of lithium. Large guest atoms such as barium were found to be electrochemically inactive but structurally important components that served to suppress crystallization and mitigate large volume changes, which leads to electrodes with better cycle life. Additional substitution of elements (such as gallium or aluminum) on Tetrel framework sites was also found to tune the reaction voltage and lithiation capacity of the materials. First principles density functional theory calculations were employed to discover new ion migration pathways and support experimental findings of new lithiated clathrate phases. The research allowed for a comprehensive understanding of how the critical structural features of clathrates, including composition, structure type, guest atom and framework type, play a role in the observed electrochemical characteristics such as reaction potential, lithiation capacity, lithium insertion mechanism, and phase evolution during lithiation. This information can help the design of future anodes for Li-ion batteries with the desired voltage and energy density characteristics.

Novel synthetic methods for silicon, germanium, and alloyed silicon-germanium clathrates were also demonstrated using electrochemical oxidation of precursors in high temperature reactors employing solid-state or metal flux electrolytes. The effect of precursor and reaction conditions on the products were studied to elucidate the formation mechanisms. The electrochemical synthesis approach for clathrates can lead to preparation of new clathrates and other related materials with improved control over product formation.

The new knowledge gained related to the clathrate atomic and electronic structures, electrochemical properties, and synthetic methods will not only greatly contribute to the knowledge base of clathrates, but could also aid the development of new materials using clathrates in applications such as energy storage, superconductors, and thermoelectrics. The project also supported education and training of students from materials science, physics, and chemistry. The students gained skills in solid-state materials synthesis and characterization, structural determination, synchrotron X-ray diffraction and pair distribution function analysis, electroanalytical methods, and density functional theory calculations. The project supported student exchanges between Arizona State University and the University of Delaware to provide graduate students working on the project exposure to electroanalytical and battery techniques, solid-state synthesis methods, and refinement techniques for X-ray diffraction and pair distribution function analysis. The students also gained experience performing synchrotron measurements during two on-site beamtime experiments at the Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron (DESY) in Germany and Diamond Light Source in the UK. Results from the project were included in 2 Ph.D. dissertations, 10 peer-reviewed journal articles (including publications co-authored with collaborators from Germany, Spain, and Sweden) and disseminated in numerous presentations and seminars, including in international conferences. When possible, journal articles were published as open-access to make results widely accessible.


Last Modified: 01/13/2023
Modified by: Candace K Chan
